metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Simultaneous observation dataset of  land surface temperature in the lower of Heihe River Basin on Aug. 01, 2014
metadata.description:
The aim of the simultaneous observation of land surface temperature is obtaining the land surface temperature for different kinds of underlying surface, including the lager areas of homogeneous vegetation with high coverage, water, and concrete floor, while the thermal imager go into the experimental areas of the low reaches. All the land surface temperature data will be used for validation of the retrieved land surface temperature from thermal imager and the analysis of the scale effect of the land surface temperature, and finally serve for the validation of the plausibility checks of the surface temperature product from remote sensing.
1.	Observation time
On 1 August, 2014
2.	Observation samples
Three field samples were chosen in the fly zone, which were large areas of homogeneous vegetation (with high coverage), water, and concrete floor.
3.	Observation method
Surface temperature values were observed continuously for each sample using handheld infrared thermometers during the imager went into the flying area.
4.	Instrument parameters and calibration
The field of view of the handheld infrared thermometer is one degree and the emissivity was assumed to be 0.95. All instruments were calibrated on 31 July, 2014 using a black body.
5.	Data storage
All the observation data were stored in an excel.

background: The "Heihe River Basin Ecological-Hydrological Process Comprehensive Remote Sensing Observation Joint Experiment" focuses on the core scientific objectives of integrated research on the ecological-hydrological system of the Heihe River Basin. Based on the established observation system in the Heihe River Basin and the results of the "Heihe Comprehensive Remote Sensing Joint Experiment" conducted from 2007 to 2009, researchers from multiple disciplines, institutions, and projects will conduct a multi-scale comprehensive observation experiment in the Heihe River Basin from 2012 to 2015, utilizing a combination of satellite and aerial remote sensing as well as ground observations. Basin science is the practice of Earth system science at the basin scale. This aligns with the international trend in basin science research, focusing on the forefront of comprehensive Earth system science research while also addressing significant national strategic needs in environmental construction and integrated management of river basins in western China. Developing basin observation systems and conducting comprehensive observation experiments are also important prerequisites for advancing basin science. Establishing an integrated remote sensing-ground observation system at the basin level is a significant trend in current Earth surface system scientific research. From 2007 to 2009, with the support of the Chinese Academy of Sciences' Western Action Plan Phase II project "Synchronous Remote Sensing-Ground Observation Experiment and Comprehensive Simulation Platform Construction in the Heihe River Basin," we collaborated with the National Key Basic Research Development Program project "Theory and Methods for Coordinated Inversion of Surface Ecological Environment Factors Using Active and Passive Remote Sensing" to carry out the "Heihe Comprehensive Remote Sensing Joint Experiment." The successful completion of this experiment has provided a solid scientific foundation and accumulated valuable experience for conducting a new round of experimental research based on it.
research objective: The overall goal of the experiment is to significantly enhance the observational capabilities of watershed ecology and hydrological processes, establish an internationally leading watershed observation system, and improve the application of remote sensing in integrated watershed ecological-hydrological research and water resource management. Specific objectives in basic observation include: establishing a watershed observation system that supports watershed scientific research and comprehensive water resource management; finely observing various components of the watershed water cycle to obtain multi-scale observational data; and acquiring multi-scale observational data to understand the dynamic changes of inland river basin ecosystems. In terms of remote sensing products and validation, the objectives include: based on comprehensive experiments, producing a set of high-precision remote sensing products that support integrated watershed-ecological-hydrological research; and conducting validation experiments to verify remote sensing models and products. The application objectives are to use comprehensive observational data and remote sensing products in upstream cold region distributed hydrological models, midstream surface water-groundwater-crop growth coupling models, and downstream ecological water consumption models, thereby enhancing the application capabilities of remote sensing in integrated watershed ecological-hydrological research and water resource management through empirical studies.
challenges: There is a lack of remote sensing products that can analyze watershed water cycles and ecological processes from a holistic perspective. At the watershed scale, surface heterogeneity is more pronounced, and the diversity of landscape types in inland river basins leads to significant variations in many parameters of water cycles and ecological processes. This necessitates remote sensing products with higher spatial and temporal resolution, as well as relatively consistent spatiotemporal resolution. However, many existing global remote sensing products do not meet this demand. There is also a lack of mature methodologies for applying remote sensing to eco-hydrological models. There is considerable debate regarding the extent to which remote sensing can enhance our understanding of eco-hydrological processes and its overall usefulness.
methods: The remote sensing sensors carried out in the aviation remote sensing experiment include LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers. We are collaborating on the National Key Basic Research Development Program project "Theory and Methods for Coordinated Inversion of Main and Passive Remote Sensing Elements of Terrestrial Ecological Environment," conducting the "Heihe Comprehensive Remote Sensing Joint Experiment." Two nested experimental areas of 30km×30km and 5.5km×5.5km have been established in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin in the Zhangye area. We will select three key experimental areas in the Heihe River Basin to carry out enhanced and long-term observation experiments.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for observing surface temperature in an ecological hydrological experiment?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of handheld infrared thermometers to perform continuous manual synchronous observations of surface temperatures during the flight of a thermal imager over uniform surfaces such as vegetation, water bodies, and cement ground.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in acquiring remote sensing products for ecological and hydrological research at a watershed scale?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the lack of remote sensing products capable of analyzing watershed water cycles and ecological processes as a whole, due to the pronounced surface heterogeneity and diverse landscape types in inland river basins, which require higher spatial and temporal resolution remote sensing products.

Definition.Question: What are the key considerations for ensuring the accuracy of remote sensing data in ecological and hydrological studies?
Definition.Answer: Ensuring the accuracy of remote sensing data in ecological and hydrological studies involves conducting ground-based observations for validation, calibrating instruments before data collection, and addressing scale effects through high coverage and consistent surface observations, as demonstrated in the synchronized surface temperature observations in Heihe River's downstream area.

Definition.Question: What challenges are typically encountered when developing remote sensing products for analyzing river basin water cycles and ecological processes?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in developing remote sensing products for river basin water cycles and ecological processes include the need for high spatial and temporal resolution data to capture heterogeneous landscapes and dynamic changes, as well as the lack of mature methodologies for integrating remote sensing data into eco-hydrological models effectively.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of obtaining high-resolution remote sensing products in heterogeneous basin landscapes compare to the challenges of integrating remote sensing data into eco-hydrological models?
Comparison.Answer: Obtaining high-resolution remote sensing products is challenged by the need for improved spatial and temporal resolution to accurately capture diverse landscape features. Integrating these products into eco-hydrological models is further complicated by the lack of mature methodologies to effectively utilize remote sensing data, requiring innovative approaches to enhance understanding of eco-hydrological processes.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred for assessing the accuracy of remote sensing temperature data in ecological and hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The methodologies involve using handheld infrared thermometers to conduct synchronous ground observations during aerial thermal imaging flights. This approach supports the validation of surface temperature retrieved from airborne thermal imagers by providing high-coverage, homogeneous surface temperature data across various terrains such as vegetation, water bodies, and cement surfaces.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can be interpreted from the need for high spatial and temporal resolution in remote sensing products for analyzing watershed processes?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the significant heterogeneity of the watershed surfaces, which requires remote sensing products that offer both high spatial and temporal resolution. This is necessary to accurately capture the rapid changes in water cycle and ecological parameters across the diverse landscape types of inland river basins. Current global remote sensing products may not meet these requirements, suggesting a need for more refined and consistent datasets.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of remote sensing data with ecological-hydrological models be interpreted in terms of improving research on watershed processes?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration involves using comprehensive observation data and high-precision remote sensing products to enhance distributed hydrological models in cold regions, as well as surface water-groundwater-crop growth coupled models in midstream areas and ecological water consumption models downstream. This approach aims to empirically improve the application of remote sensing in integrated ecological-hydrological research and water resource management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of creating high spatial and temporal resolution remote sensing products for analyzing basin-scale water cycles and ecological processes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges stem from the heterogeneity of the landscape at the basin scale and the diverse types of inland river basin landscapes, which result in dramatic variations in water cycle and ecological process parameters. These require remote sensing products with higher spatial and temporal resolution and consistent spatiotemporal resolution, which current global remote sensing products do not fully meet.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for a sophisticated methodology to apply remote sensing in eco-hydrological models within the field of basin-scale research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a lack of mature methodology for applying remote sensing to eco-hydrological models. The utility and extent to which remote sensing can enhance our understanding of eco-hydrological processes is still debatable, indicating the need for a more refined methodological approach.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the requirement for synchronized surface temperature observations to support aerial thermal imager flight data in validating surface temperature retrievals?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Synchronized surface temperature observations are needed to support aerial thermal imager flight data for validation and scale effect analysis. These observations help ensure the authenticity of remote sensing surface temperature products by providing comparative data from high-coverage homogeneous surfaces such as vegetation, water bodies, and cement grounds.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using handheld infrared thermometers for synchronous surface temperature observation on the accuracy of remote sensing verification?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using handheld infrared thermometers allows for continuous manual synchronous observations of surface temperatures, which supports the validation of remote sensing data from aerial thermal cameras. This method provides crucial ground-truth data for verifying and analyzing the scale effects of remotely sensed surface temperature products, enhancing the accuracy and reliability of remote sensing verification.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of multi-disciplinary and multi-agency research efforts impact the development of watershed observation systems in the Heihe River Basin?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of multi-disciplinary and multi-agency research efforts significantly enhances the capability to observe ecological and hydrological processes in the watershed. It facilitates the establishment of an advanced watershed observation system, which can improve the application of remote sensing in integrated ecological and hydrological research and water resource management, aligning with major national strategic needs for environmental construction and watershed management in Western China.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of lacking high-resolution remote sensing products on understanding water cycle and ecological processes in diverse inland river basin landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The absence of high-resolution remote sensing products makes it challenging to analyze water cycle and ecological processes comprehensively due to the pronounced surface heterogeneity and varied landscape types in inland river basins. This limitation can hinder the ability to capture the dynamic changes of ecosystem processes accurately, thereby reducing the effectiveness of ecological-hydrological integration research and water resource management within the basin.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind establishing a comprehensive watershed observation system for ecological and hydrological processes in the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to significantly enhance observation capabilities of ecological and hydrological processes, establish an internationally leading watershed observation system, and improve the application ability of remote sensing in integrated watershed ecological and hydrological research and water resource management.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to conduct simultaneous surface temperature observations on uniform vegetation, water bodies, and cement surfaces during thermal imager flights?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Conducting simultaneous surface temperature observations on these surfaces is crucial to support the validation and scale effect analysis of surface temperature inversion from aerial thermal imager data, ensuring the authenticity of remote sensing surface temperature products.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended goals of integrating satellite, aerial, and ground observation methods in the Heihe River Basin's multi-scale comprehensive observation experiments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended goals are to prepare a set of high-precision remote sensing products that support integrated watershed-ecological hydrology research, conduct authenticity verification tests, and enhance the application of remote sensing in ecological-hydrological integration and water resource management.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methodological challenges faced in integrating remote sensing data with ground observations for analyzing watershed-scale ecological and hydrological processes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The challenges include a lack of remote sensing products that can analyze watershed-scale water cycle and ecological processes comprehensively. The heterogeneity of the surface at the watershed scale, combined with the diverse landscape types in inland river basins, necessitates higher spatial and temporal resolution remote sensing products. Current global remote sensing products often do not meet these requirements.

Enablement.Question: What observational technologies have enabled the comprehensive remote sensing experiments in the Heihe River Basin to support ecological and hydrological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The technologies include the use of airborne remote sensing sensors such as LIDAR, imaging spectrometers, thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers. These technologies are integrated into a multi-scale observation system that combines satellite, aerial, and ground observations to enhance the understanding of ecological and hydrological processes in the basin.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or strategies enable the effective integration of remote sensing data with ecological-hydrological models to improve water resource management in river basins?
Enablement.Answer: Effective integration is enabled by developing high-resolution remote sensing products that match the spatial and temporal resolutions required for capturing the dynamic changes in inland river basin ecosystems. Additionally, using comprehensive observation data and remote sensing products in empirical studies enhances their application in ecological-hydrological models, thus improving water resource management.

Expectation.Question: Why might comprehensive remote sensing products struggle to effectively analyze watershed water cycles and ecological processes at a basin scale?
Expectation.Answer: Comprehensive remote sensing products might struggle due to the pronounced surface heterogeneity at the basin scale and the diverse landscape types in inland river basins. These factors lead to significant variations in many parameters of water cycles and ecological processes, necessitating remote sensing products with higher spatial and temporal resolution and consistent spatiotemporal resolution, which current global remote sensing products may not adequately provide.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected outcomes of using integrated observation systems for watershed science research and water resource management?
Expectation.Answer: The expected outcomes include significantly enhanced abilities to observe watershed ecological and hydrological processes, the establishment of internationally leading watershed observation systems, and improved application of remote sensing in integrated watershed eco-hydrological research and water resource management. This includes acquiring multi-scale observational data of water cycle components and ecosystem dynamics, supporting the development of high-accuracy remote sensing products, and applying these data to various regional models to improve remote sensing applications in the field.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using handheld infrared thermometers for synchronized surface temperature observations in supporting remote sensing validation processes?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of handheld infrared thermometers for synchronized surface temperature observations is effective in providing concurrent ground truth data during aerial thermal imaging flights. This method supports the validation of remotely sensed surface temperature products by ensuring that the data collected reflects real-time, high-accuracy measurements of surface conditions, which is critical for accurate remote sensing analysis and scale effect studies.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges faced in achieving high spatial and temporal resolution in remote sensing products for analyzing inland river basin ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in achieving high spatial and temporal resolution in remote sensing products include the pronounced heterogeneity of the landscape at the basin scale and the diverse nature of inland river basin ecosystems. These factors necessitate remote sensing products with consistent spatial and temporal resolution, which current global remote sensing products often lack. This makes it difficult to capture the rapid changes in water cycle and ecological process parameters required for comprehensive analysis.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the integration of airborne remote sensing with ground-based observations enhance the development of high-precision datasets for ecological and hydrological research?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating airborne remote sensing with ground-based observations can enhance high-precision datasets by combining broad spatial coverage from airborne sensors with the detailed, accurate measurements obtained from ground-based methods. This integration allows for a more complete and validated dataset, which supports the development of high-precision remote sensing products. These products are essential for ecological and hydrological research as they provide comprehensive data necessary for model calibration, validation, and improving understanding of complex processes within river basins.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the methods used for collecting synchronized surface temperature data in the context of downstream ecological hydrology experiments.
Request/Directive.Answer: The synchronized surface temperature data collection method involved the use of a handheld infrared thermometer to perform continuous manual synchronized observations when a thermal imager flew over large homogeneous areas of vegetation, water bodies, and cement ground. The emissivity of the thermometer was set to 0.95, and it had a field of view of 1°. Calibration of the instruments was performed on July 31, 2014.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in creating remote sensing products that can effectively analyze watershed water cycles and ecological processes at the basin scale.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the lack of remote sensing products capable of analyzing water cycles and ecological processes holistically, with high spatial and temporal resolution due to the surface heterogeneity and diverse landscape types within inland river basins. Current global remote sensing products do not meet these needs, and there is also a lack of mature methodologies for applying remote sensing to eco-hydrological models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential methods for enhancing the accuracy of remote sensing products in supporting watershed-scale eco-hydrological integrated research.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential methods for enhancing accuracy include developing high-precision remote sensing products based on comprehensive experiments, conducting authenticity verification tests to validate remote sensing models and products, and utilizing integrated observation data and remote sensing products in various hydrological models for different zones within a watershed to improve their application in eco-hydrological research and water resource management.
